references: Bickham, J. W., M. D. Springer, and B. J. Gallaway. 1984. Distributional survey of the yellow mud turtle (KINOSTERNON FLAVESCENS) in Iowa, Illinois, and Missouri: a proposed endangered species. Southwest Nat. 29:123-132.

Berry, J. F., and C. M. Berry. 1984. A re-analysis of geographic variation and systematics in the yellow mud turtle, KINOSTERNON FLAVESCENS (Agassiz). Annals of Carnegie Museum of Natural History 53:185-206.
Iverson, J. B. 1989. The Arizona mud turtle, KINOSTERNON FLAVESCENS ARIZONENSE (Kinosternidae), in Arizona and Sonora. Southwest. Nat. 34:356-368.

Serb, J. M., C. A. Phillips, and J. B. Iverson. 2001. Molecular phylogeny and biogeography of KINOSTERNON FLAVESCENS based on complete mitochondrial control region sequences. Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution 18:149-162.
habitat_description:
The range for the Arizona mud turtle includes the Sonoran Desert of southern Arizona and adjacent Mexico (Serb et al. 2001). In general, habitat comprises of desert, riparian areas, or herbaceous wetlands and grasslands; inhabiting various quiet or slow-flowing bodies of water, usually with soft mud or sand bottom, in areas of desert, and in temporary water, may travel overland (Serb et al. 2001). It burrows in or using soil, fallen logs or debris (Serb et al. 2001). 

Associated with herbaceous grasslands and herbaceous wetlands.
